name: phaseolus-vulgaris
definition: Bean is a herbaceous annual plant grown worldwide for its edible dry seeds.
description:
Bean is a herbaceous annual plant grown worldwide for its edible dry seeds, commonly called beans.

The bean can be bushy, vine-like or climbing depending on the variety being grown.

It range greatly in size from the bushy varieties 20 to 60 centimeters in height; to vines or runner beans which can reach 2 to 3 meters in length.

The leaves grow alternately on the stems, are green or purple in color and are divided into 3 oval leaflets with smooth edges.

The leaves can grow 6 to 15 centimeters long and 3 to 11 centimeters wide.

The bean produces white, pink, lilac or purple flowers which are approximately 1 centimeter in diameter.

Flowers grow in pods, each pod containing 4 to 6 smooth, kidney-shaped beans.

The bean is used as a pulse and green vegetable, eaten fresh or cooked.

It can be dried, cooked in sauce and canned.

Bean leaf is also occasionally used as a vegetable and the straw as fodder.

Bean plants are annual plants and last only one growing season.

Beans are warm-season crops and should be planted after all danger of frost has passed and the soil has warmed.

They grow best at soil temperatures between 15.5 and 29°C and are sensitive to cold temperatures and frosts.

Beans will grow best in a fertile, well-draining soil and perform best in full sunlight.

Seeds should be planted 2.5 to 3.5 centimeters deep.

Bush beans should be planted 5 to 10 centimeters apart allowing 0.6 to 0.9 meters between rows.

Pole beans should be provided with a pole or trellis to climb on to support the weight of the pods and allow light to penetrate to all parts of the plant

Beans are grown on every continent except Antarctica.

Worldwide, 27 million tonnes of dried beans were grown in 2016. Myanmar was the largest producer.

The bean is a highly variable species that has a long history of cultivation.

Is thought to have originated in Mexico more than 100,000 years ago.

Bean was actually domesticated separately at two different geographic locations in Mesoamerica and the southern Andes.

contextual.caption:
All wild bean members have a climbing habit, but many cultivars are classified either as bush beans or dwarf beans, or as pole beans or climbing beans, depending on their style of growth.

Bush beans will grow erect without any support and require less care than pole varieties.

featured.caption: Bean pods are 8 to 20 centimeters long and 1 to 1.5 centimeters wide and can range in color from green to yellow or black to purple.
